Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: The planning session is informal, and the timeline can still shift without major impact
Story: I sat on the couch, laptop open, half-listening to the project manager’s voice crackling through my headphones. My partner slumped beside me, eyes red, clutching her phone. She’d just gotten a terse email from her boss—her big project wasn’t good enough, apparently. She needed me, I could feel it in the way she leaned closer, silent but hopeful. I wanted to put my arm around her, to tell her she was brilliant, that her boss was wrong. But the team was waiting for my input. They needed my estimates for the new feature, and I knew if I didn’t speak up now, the whole plan could get muddled. My manager expected me to be precise, to think ahead, even if the session was casual. I could see the chat window blinking, my name tagged. My partner’s hand brushed mine, seeking comfort. My mind raced, torn between the urge to close the laptop and be present for her, and the responsibility to my team. The weight of both roles pressed down, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
